clusters.title: Teen charged after pregnant woman and unborn baby die in Sydney crash
clusters.neutral_headline: Pregnant Woman and Unborn Baby Die in Sydney Car Crash

items.title: Teen charged after pregnant woman and unborn baby die in Sydney crash
items.standfirst: The woman was with her husband and three-year-old son when was hit last night.
items.content: A family is grieving a mother and her unborn child who were killed after being struck by a car in Sydney's north.A teenage driver with a provisional licence has been charged and now faces up to 10 years in prison.The woman was with her husband and three-year-old son when she was hit while walking across the entrance to a car park on George Street in Hornsby about 8pm yesterday.READ MORE: Widespread storms threaten heavy rain, damaging winds and large hail A Kia Carnival turning into the car park of the Hornsby Railway Station stopped to let them pass.A white BMW driven by a P-plater allegedly slammed into the back of the Kia, which then hit the woman.Paramedics treated the 33-year-old, who was eight months pregnant, before she was rushed to Westmead Hospital in a critical condition.Neither mother nor baby could be saved.READ MORE: Australia's beef industry welcomes Trump's sudden backflipNSW Police Traffic and Highway Patrol Command Assistant Commissioner David Driver said the crash was "very confronting" for first responders."It's particularly tragic when people pass away and indeed when there's children involved," Driver said."This is a terrible, terrible story."P-plate driver Aaron Papazoglu was taken to hospital for mandatory testing before being allowed to go home to nearby Wahroonga.Police who watched dashcam video of the incident arrested the 19-year-old about 12.45am on Millewa Avenue in Wahroonga.He was taken to Hornsby Police Station and charged with dangerous driving occasioning death – drive manner dangerous, negligent driving (occasioning death) and cause loss of foetus – death of pregnant woman.The legislation, known as Zoe's Law, was only introduced three years ago.The 48-year-old man driving the Kia Carnival was not hurt. Papazoglu remains behind bars to face Parramatta Local Court tomorrow.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: 'Terrible story': Pregnant woman killed after being hit by car in Sydney
items.standfirst: A 33-year-old woman and her unborn baby have died after being hit by a car that had been involved in a crash with another vehicle at the entrance of a car park in Hornsby.
items.content: A 33-year-old woman and her unborn baby have died after being hit by a car that had been involved in a crash with another vehicle at the entrance of a car park in Hornsby.

ai_summary: A pregnant woman and her unborn baby died in a Sydney car crash.
The woman was with her husband and three-year-old son.
The car crash occurred in Hornsby, Sydney.
The car involved had been in a prior crash.
Police are investigating the circumstances of the accident.

clusters.title: Amyl and the Sniffers' free Melbourne gig shut down over safety fears
clusters.neutral_headline: Amyl and the Sniffers Gig Cancelled, Drinks Given Away

items.title: Amyl and the Sniffers' free Melbourne gig shut down over safety fears
items.standfirst: The band paid for $35,000 worth of drink for disappointed fans.
items.content: A free gig by Australian rockers Amyl and the Sniffers was shut down after security fences at Federation Square were breached.The free gig for all ages in Melbourne was cancelled soon after the band was due to take to the stage."Fed Square will always put safety first," MAP Co chief executive Katrina Sedgwick said. READ MORE: Severe thunderstorms sweep across south-east Queensland - and more to comeThe band just supported AC/DC in Melbourne and have just been nominated for a Grammy. Sedgwick said the concert was stopped mid-show."It came about because of multiple breaches to the perimeter fencing, which caused a very real risk of crowd crushes." "We didn't make this decision lightly. It was a really tough decision."She said at 7.40pm capacity was reached for the show.But people outside started pushing on the fencing, breaking it down, she said."At that point we announced the show was cancelled."Lead singer Amy Taylor blew up on Instagram, saying "you simply cannot imagine the tantrum I am having" at missing out on performing the free gig in the band's hometown of Melbourne."So, so, so sorry, we're really sad," Taylor said in a selfie video."We're backstage, we literally would have loved to play, we're devastated."The f---ing fences got crushed in, too many people, f---ing cops shut it down. (We're) p---ed as f---, p---ed off, and we're just really apologetic and so sorry."Fed Square said in an earlier statement it was forced to cancel the show "after multiple breaches of the perimeter fences caused a very high risk of crowd crushes"."It was unsafe for the show to continue," Fed Square said.READ MORE: Rap legend takes Aussie brand to court over name "We did not take this decision lightly and are deeply sorry for any disappointment caused, however tonight could simply not continue."Our sincere apologies to the band and their fans."Taylor and the rest of the band returned to Instagram later to say they had put $5000 bar tabs on at seven Melbourne venues- totalling $35,000, for disappointed fans to "have a drink on us"."We're not doggin' ya, it's because a bunch of people rushed the f---ing barriers and so it wasn't safe, and especially because it was all ages, we just can't have that, we don't want anyone having a s--- time," Taylor said.Taylor also posted on her Instagram Story that she would be dealing with her frustrations by getting "blackout drunk somewhere in mourning".

items.title: 'Wild' night in Melbourne sees band’s gig cancelled, $35k in free drinks
items.standfirst: After their homecoming Fed Square gig was cancelled over security fears, Amyl and the Sniffers put $5,000 behind the bar at seven live music venues around Melbourne.
items.content: After their homecoming Fed Square gig was cancelled over security fears, Amyl and the Sniffers put $5,000 behind the bar at seven live music venues around Melbourne.

ai_summary: Amyl and the Sniffers' free Melbourne gig was canceled.
The cancellation was due to safety concerns.
The band provided $35,000 worth of free drinks.
The drinks were distributed at seven live music venues.
The event was a homecoming gig for the band.

items.standfirst: Hit hard by last weekend's loss to Italy, the Wallabies are desperate to rebound when they face Ireland in Dublin on Sunday morning.
items.content: Hit hard by last weekend's loss to Italy, the Wallabies are desperate to rebound when they face Ireland in Dublin on Sunday morning.

ai_summary: The Wallabies are determined to improve their performance.

The Wallabies are focused on a strong showing.

clusters.title: Couple who bought unit six weeks ago say they couldn't afford it now
clusters.neutral_headline: Couple Unable to Afford Unit Purchased Six Weeks Ago

items.title: Couple who bought unit six weeks ago say they couldn't afford it now
items.standfirst: A young couple bought a one-bedroom unit in inner-city Brisbane using the government’s 5 per cent deposit scheme. Around the same time, a two-bedroom brick walk-up in the same suburb sold for just over $1m, highlighting soaring unit prices.
items.content: A young couple bought a one-bedroom unit in inner-city Brisbane using the government’s 5 per cent deposit scheme. Around the same time, a two-bedroom brick walk-up in the same suburb sold for just over $1m, highlighting soaring unit prices.

ai_summary: A couple bought a unit in Brisbane six weeks ago.
They now cannot afford the unit they purchased.
They used the government's 5 percent deposit scheme.
A nearby unit sold for over $1 million.
The article highlights rising unit prices in Brisbane.

clusters.title: $4 trillion in super at risk as market meltdown fears spread
clusters.neutral_headline: Fears of Market Meltdown Spread, Super at Risk

items.title: $4 trillion in super at risk as market meltdown fears spread
items.standfirst: Markets are heading south over fears about the US economy and interest rates not falling. Analysts fear mortgage holders and superannuates are in the firing line.
items.content: Markets are heading south over fears about the US economy and interest rates not falling. Analysts fear mortgage holders and superannuates are in the firing line.

ai_summary: Markets are declining due to concerns about the US economy.
Fears are growing about interest rates not falling.

$4 trillion in superannuation is potentially at risk.
The article discusses the impact of market volatility.

clusters.title: There's a conundrum in the Liberal net zero position — and no way to right it
clusters.neutral_headline: Australian Liberal Party Faces Net Zero Policy Confusion

items.title: There's a conundrum in the Liberal net zero position — and no way to right it
items.standfirst: Liberal shadow cabinet members landed on a plan that has left many inside and outside the party bewildered and confused.
items.content: Liberal shadow cabinet members landed on a plan that has left many inside and outside the party bewildered and confused.

clusters.title: Hair loss drug users say psychological side effects left them 'crumbling'
clusters.neutral_headline: Users Report Psychological Side Effects from Hair Loss Drug

items.title: Hair loss drug users say psychological side effects left them 'crumbling'
items.standfirst: A vocal minority of finasteride users speak out about the long-lasting mental side effects of the hair loss drug, as telehealth ads for the medication surge on social media.
items.content: A vocal minority of finasteride users speak out about the long-lasting mental side effects of the hair loss drug, as telehealth ads for the medication surge on social media.

ai_summary: Some finasteride users report long-lasting mental side effects from the drug.
